metadata.title: Fabrications and Applications of ZnO Nanomaterials in Flexible Functional Devices-A Review

sections.text: KEYWORDS Application; function device; review; ZnO

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Recently metal-oxide semiconductors materials have become a hot research topic due to they are widely used in different fields. Nanostructured metal oxides such as TiO2, zinc oxide (ZnO), SnO2, GeN, CdS, Fe2O3, and WO3 have shown stable transport properties in different functional devices. Among them, ZnO, as an II–VI semiconductor, which has the necessary excellent conditions of the ultraviolet and blue emissions because of its unique of chemical and physical properties of a huge direct energy gap (around 3.37 eV) and a huge exciton binding energy (60meV),[1] which makes it being advantageous over many other nanomaterials. Another advantage is its large electromechanical coupling, particularly along the c-direction of the crystalline. Further yet, ZnO is well suited for production of nanostructures, so that it can be used for devices. ZnO nanostructures and their integration with the mainstream semiconductor materials such as Si,[2] GaN,[3–5] TiO2,
[6] and organic semiconductors[7] is an important part in the research field of flexible functional devices based on ZnO in recent years.
In this article, major methods for fabrications of ZnO nanomaterials are discussed and a critical review of their recent applications in flexible functional devices is given. Firstly, the synthesis methods of ZnO nanomaterials, such as sputtering, sol-gel, atomic layer deposition (ALD), all-inkjetprinting approach, electrochemical deposition (ECD), hydrothermal method are reviewed. Secondly, the application of ZnO in solar cell is discussed. Lastly, supercapacitors (SCs), flexible piezoelectric nanogenerators (NGs), ultraviolet photodetectors (PDs), photodiodes, porous three-dimensional (3-D) ceramics, functional surface coating, and sensors
applications exploiting the unique properties of ZnO nanostructures are discussed.

sections.heading: Synthesis methods of ZnO nanomaterials
sections.text: The applications of ZnO nanomaterials involves multiple fields, and different applications have different requirements for ZnO, including film thickness, crystal orientation, grain size, and surface roughness. Currently, a lot of methods have been established for ZnO nanomaterials synthesis. We will consider the methods of preparation of ZnO nanomaterials proposed by various scientists, as shown below.

sections.heading: Magnetron sputtering
sections.text:
Magnetron sputtering is one of the most widely applied methods of preparing ZnO nanomaterials at present, because it has the advantages of high deposition rate, low deposition temperature, easy-control preparation process, and the like. The sputtering is a kind of work that can be used to bombard the target material with high energy granules, which can cause atoms or molecules of target material to be sputtered and deposited to the surface of the liner. According to the different sputtering materials, magnetron sputtering including three types such as radio frequency (RF) magnetron sputtering, direct current (DC) magnetron sputtering.
Hou et al.[8] used DC magnetron sputtering in an Ar/O2 (flow ratio 50/50 sccm) gas atmosphere in their work. In the deposition process of ZnO thin films, Hou et al. used a

100 300mm2 Zn target. They deposited ZnO films with a nominal thickness of 3 lm onto a 50 lm thick commercially available Al foil, and the temperature stayed below 80 C. They kept the rotation speed of drum-type substrate, which the constant speed is 50 rpm, and this enhanced the uniformity of the films over a 50 70mm2 deposition area. They used XRD and SEM to analyze the microscope of samples. From the result of tests, the growth of films with c-axis (002) orientation is a dense polycrystalline with a columnar mode.
In order to synthesize the Ag-doped ZnO NRs, hydrothermal-RF magnetron system was used by Uddin et al.[9] In an Ar environment, ZnO thin films were deposited by RF magnetron with a ZnO target. Their thickness is about 120 nm, which deposited on a polyimide/polytetrafluoroethylene (PI/PTFE) support layer. Through the hydrothermal technique, they synthesized ZnO on the PI/PTFE substrates with coating the ZnO seed layer. They obtained ZnO NRs from aqueous solutions of 4mM zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn (NO3)2 6H2O) and 4mM hexamethylenetetramine (C6H12N4, HMTA). They firstly transferred mixed solution into a Teflon-lined autoclave. Then, the ZnO seed layer, which coated on PI/PTFE substrate, was vertically immersed into the autoclave. The reaction was conducted in an autoclave oven at a temperature of 80 C. After 4 hours, the product of ZnO NRs/PI/PTFE was washed with deionizes water, and then eliminated the residual water and dried on a hotplate at 100 C for 30minutes. Under different loading times, they used RF magnetron sputtering with Ag target (99.99%) to coat Ag nanoparticles on the ZnO NRs/PI/PTFE sample in an Ar environment, finally.

sections.heading: Vacuum sputter
sections.text: A cost-effective, low-temperature vacuum-based sputter deposition process was used by Banerjee et al.[10] in an Ar atmosphere after the sputter deposition chamber evacuated. Good crystalline, highly transparent, semiconducting nanostructured ZnO films were obtained on plastic (polyethylene terephthalate) substrates that can withstand temperature more than 150 C by sputtering, using a commercially available ZnO powder (99.99%) to fabricate ZnO pellet as sputter target and to place as the upper electrode (cathode) in the sputter chamber by appropriate target holder. XRD, UV–vis spectrophotometer, and HRTEM (high resolution transmission electron microscopy) were performed to know structural properties, microstructure, and optical characterization of the as-synthesized nanocrystalline ZnO films on plastic substrate, respectively. It was confirmed that the ZnO nanomaterial can be played an important application in flexible electronics because its proper phase has an average nanoparticle size with 5–10 nm and nearly 90% visible transmittance with a wide band-gap (3.56 eV).

sections.heading: Sol–gel technique
sections.text:
Sol–gel method on the synthesis of ZnO nanomaterials has been applied because of its simple, low-cost, and highly
controlled. According to the references, this method can be divided into two categories: the spin method and dip method, namely, the sol–gel spin-coating, and the sol–gel dipping methods.
The low temperature sol–gel techniques using a solution of zinc acetate dehydrate (ZnAc, Zn (CH3COO)2 2H2O, 99%), 2-methoxyethanol (CH3OCH2CH2OH, 99%), and MEA (NH2CH2CH2OH, 99%) were used to obtained ZnO thin films by Lin et al.[11] However, the MEA was regard as catalysts of the ZnO film, and however, it was deemed to be the growing ZnO needed. The obtained products were characterized by using technique such as atomic force microscope. The prepared ZnO films clearly exhibited that the relationship between concentration and surface roughness is positively correlation. These ZnO thin films, as cathode buffer layer, are one of important devices in flexible inverted organic solar cells (IOSCs).
Duan et al.[12] successfully fabricated Al-doped ZnO transparent conducting film. In this experiment, the samples were prepared by the sol-gel spin coating technique on the flexible PI substrate. They investigated the effects of number of layers on the structure, surface morphology, and topography of the prepared samples. The study showed that all samples of different layers not only have a hexagonal crystal structure but also priority c-axis texture and good adhesion to flexible PI substrates. In addition, transmittance of bare PI substrate was analyzed using transmittance spectra. The transmittance spectra provided evidence that the average transmittances of the films, which the value is 70%, were related to a cutoff wavelength produced by PI substrates. Furthermore, after vacuum (P¼ 10 2 Pa) post-annealing, they demonstrated a greatly enhanced electrical conductivity in samples. They also acquired the lowest resistivity of 2.52 10 1Xcm in the film with 10 layers.

sections.heading: Atomic layer deposition
sections.text:
In the present study, it is fundamental for modern materials science to control the crystal growth. And the ALD is one of the chemical vapor depositions, which is a special method to compare with other depositions.
ZnO (inorganic shell), which has precise thickness, was deposited on the circular and smooth surfaces of nylon 6, 6 nanofibers by Kayaci et al.[13] using the ALD technique at 200 C. A determination was made of the surface morphology and the surface roughness of ZnO nanofibers. Under different conditions present three different average fiber diameters of core-shell nylon 6, 6-ZnO nanofibers (smooth and uniform surface Figure 1(a–c), the surface roughness increases Figure 1(d–f)), was clearly observed by SEM images. The result showed that the morphology of ZnO islands was influenced by cycle-index of the ALD. When the cycle-index of the ALD keeps increasing, and ZnO islands eventually become a continuous thin film. As a consequence, the film produced by the composition of ZnO particles that increased the surface roughness. However, the prepared films with ALD method are not only smooth, but also have a low surface roughness. As they demonstrated in their
work, it is quite unique for electrospun nanofibers to deposit conformal ZnO through ALD method.[14]
The technique of obtaining ZnO on metalized PET polymer substrates using spatial atomic layer deposition (S-ALD) was used by Sharma et al.[15] In the S-ALD method, the diethylzinc and ozone were used as the reactants. They determined that the growth of ZnO ALD changes with the number of cycles of ZnO ALD. Meanwhile, with the increasing rotation rate of the inner cylindrical drum, the growth rate of ZnO ALD was decreased. The reason for it is because of the decreasing reactants exposure time at higher rotation rates.

sections.heading: Spray pyrolysis
sections.text:
The preparation of ZnO nanomaterials by the spray pyrolysis method is the subject of much interest, in view of its simplicity, low equipment cost, minimal waste production, and non-contaminating production. It can be also used as coating applied to the huge surface. What’s more, it can be produced on a large-scale industrial production.
Rajagopalan et al.[16] prepared ZnO by spray pyrolysis method with anhydrous zinc acetate (Zn (CH3COO)2) and methanol (CH3OH) dissolved in deionized water (3:1) as precursor (0.1mol/L) solution. And ZnO was deposited on flexible substrate. In this process, by tuning the substrate temperature, one can modify the piezoelectric property of the samples and then systematically studied the effects of substrate temperature on the piezoelectric properties. The reaction in spray pyrolysis was involved the following equations (1) and (3):
Zn CH3COOHð Þ2 þ H2O þ CH3OH ! Zn2þ þ OH
þ CH4 gð Þ þ 2CH3COOH (1)
Zn2þ þ OH þ CH4 gð Þ þ 2CH3COOH ! Zn OHð Þ2 (2)
Zn OHð Þ2 ! ZnO sð Þ þ H2O gð Þ (3) The pH of the solution at 4.0 was decreased via adding the glycol acetic acid, before the experiment. With the substrate temperature at 300 C, the samples showed the best output peak voltage around 1.91V. A direct relation between piezoelectric output and intrinsic defects was carried out using photoluminescence (PL) spectra. The PL spectra illustrated that a certain number of defects existing in the nanostructures, and the effect of morphology and defects level of ZnO on the piezoelectric output. In addition, the polycrystalline behavior for all prepared samples was dominant at 400 C. Unlike other thin films that exhibited amorphous behavior.

sections.heading: Electrochemical deposition
sections.text:
The ECD is a simple, fast and inexpensive method, and its greatest advantage is for large surface area treatment. The disadvantage is that voltage and current may be unstable, resulting in the appearing of non-uniform nanomaterials, affecting its performance. Using an ECD method, Salman et al.[17] obtained ZnO films onto indium tin oxides (ITO) conductive substrates for three deposition times (5, 10, and 15minutes). As the anode and cathode material they used Zn foil and ITO substrates, respectively, and as the electrolyte precursor they used Zn (NO3)2 5H2O. The ECD of the films was carried out in the cell, which is a simple homemade container made from Teflon with cylindrical shape of 9.5 cm internal radius and 3.6 cm external radius. The diversity of the morphological measurements and field emission
Figure 1. Representative SEM images of (a) 8%-nylon 6,6/FA, (b) 5%-nylon 6,6/HFIP, (c) 8%-nylon 6,6/HFIP nanofibers; and (d) 8%-nylon 6,6/FA-ZnO, (e) 5%-nylon 6,6/HFIP-ZnO, (f) 8%-nylon 6,6/HFIP-ZnO core-shell nanofibers. The insets show higher-magnification images.[1]
scanning electron microscopy analyses were implemented using XRD and ZEISS equipment, respectively. Based on detection results, Salman et al. noted that the deposited films with wurtzite phase were polycrystalline in nature and the nominal diameter of particles of the films was between 50 and 100 nm. Besides, ZnO thin films were used to prepare a dye sensitized solar cell (DSSC) with conversion efficiency 2.7%.

sections.heading: All-inkjet-printing approach
sections.text: Compared with other methods, all-inkjet-printing approach is not just low cost, simple and mass production. It has an excellent benefit that can obtain the construction of flexible semiconductor thin film patterns with an accurate shape. Frequent nozzle clogging is the common phenomenon in traditional printing methods, but it can be solved in current research field. All-inkjet-printing approach, so-called additive manufacturing, was used by Tran et al.[18] They used a facile sol–gel method to prepare the precursor ink of ZnO thin films, which contained only one kind of zinc salt, which is soluble in solvents. To avoid the nozzle clogging, they filtered the large size particles in the ink. Then they printed ZnO thin films with the desired pattern by using inkjet printer devices under different substrate temperatures. After printing, the effect of substrate temperature on the morphology of the film was invested by Tran et al. Their study showed that as the temperature of the substrate increases, and the film becomes more homogeneous. In the preparation of ZnO nanorods (NRs), Sun et al.[19] used the inkjet printing technique to deposited the ZnO seed layer, and then grew ZnO NRs by hydrothermal method, which is different from Tran’s approach. S anchez et al.[20] introduced that ZnO layer, which deposited by inkjet printing method, can be used in inverted polymer solar cells.

sections.heading: Hydrothermal technique
sections.text:
As a rapid, simple, economical, and low-cost approach for large-scale production process technique, hydrothermal method is industrially the most attractive. As is well known, this method has been in use for synthesis ZnO nanostructures, including nanotubes,[21] NRs,[22–25] nanoparticles,[26] nanocandles,[27] and nanowires (NWs).[28,29] However, it also has a drawback: the hydrothermal reaction is carried out in the closed system that the crystal growth information can only be obtained from the surface structure since it cannot be directly observed.
Deng et al.[30] conducted a study concerning a low temperature hydrothermal method for growth ZnO NRs on flexible kapton substrate. They obtained ZnO NRs from an aqueous solutions of Zn (NO3)2 6H2O and HMTA. The as grown ZnO NR, different from other literatures of cylinder,[31] had regular hexagonal prism with diameter of 100 nm and length of 600 nm. On the basis of the voltage mapping they reported that there are two different electric potentials generated by the ZnO NR under the external force. And the voltage between the electrodes is about 20mV. Moreover, they indicated that this NR-based piezoelectric array could be used for tactile sensing without interference among adjacent units.
A hydrothermal method was also used in the work of Shin et al.[32] In the hydrothermal synthesis process of vanadium (V)-doped ZnO nanosheets (NSs), Zn (NO3)2 6H2O) and HMTA were mixed in deionized to prepare the solution. And then add vanadium pent-oxide (V2O5) as dopant to the solution. After that, the solution was stirred at 60 C and maintained for 2 hours, and then put it in the oven for 5 hours. Finally, they used DI water to wash the products of V-doped ZnO NSs and dried in an oven at 150 C for 3 hours. According to SEM and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy images, Shin et al. found that the morphology of the assynthesized V-doped ZnO NSs was composed of multiple NSs, which looks like a flower (Figure 2(a)). They also unveiled the elemental compositions of the NSs where O (red), Zn (green), and V (yellow) elements were extracted (Figure 2(b)).
Li et al.[33] fabricated ZnO quantum dot (QD) decorated Zn2SnO4 (ZTO) NWs. According to their research findings, the ZnO QD decorated ZTO NWs might be adapted to the flexible optoelectronics due to excellent devices properties, such as ultrahigh light-to-dark current ratio, specific detectivity, and photoconductive gain, high response speed, and excellent thermal stability and long-term stability. Like Shin et al., Li et al. used hydrothermal method to prepare samples. In this process, the precursor solution was heated for 3 hours at 95 C. They did this to grow ZnO QDs on the ZTO NW surface.
The technique of obtaining high photocatalytic performance B-doped ZnO (B-ZnO) microspheres on ITO-coated PET substrates using hydrothermal method was used by Yu et al.[34] In the hydrothermal method the aqueous solution of Zn (NO3)2 6H2O and HMTA aqueous solution be used as precursor solution. Using the first principles calculation, they determined that the reason for the reduction in band gap is that the B atoms tend to take up the octahedral interstice positions. In conclusion, the B-ZnO/PET-ITO plays a prospect role in the application of photocatalytic devices.
Figure 2. (a) SEM of the as-synthesized V-doped ZnO NSs. (b) The element composition image of ZnO NSs.[32]
Application of ZnO nanomaterials in flexible function devices
ZnO materials has huge electromechanical coupling (along the c-direction), wide energy gap and exciton binding energy value of 3.7 eV and 60meV, respectively. Excellent performances like these represent that ZnO nanomaterials are widely used in many areas and play important roles in optical and electrical applications.

sections.heading: Solar cell
sections.text:
Inverted organic solar cells IOSCs have attracted significant interest, due to better longterm air stability and low work function metal cathode than conventional organic solar cells.
Efficient and flexible inverter organic solar cells, which used silver nanowire/ZnO as transparent electrodes, were fabricated by Song et al. (Figure 3).[35] In this process, ZnO precursor solution was spin-cast on top of the silver nanowires (Ag NWs) film coated glass and PES substrate. Song et al. through SEM images observed that Ag NWs film, which grow on PES substrate, have superior mechanical flexibility. More importantly, their sheet resistance has a low value of 13 Xsq 1, and transmittance is also high to 93%. The IOSCs based Ag NWs/PES showed excellent bending reliability, a power conversion efficient (PCE) of 7.21%, and their PCE was not affected by bending, even after multiple deforming bent with a bending strain of 2.0%. Different from Song et al., Jin et al.[36] utilized ZnO nanomaterial as electrical transmission layer to fabricate IOSCs with high power conversion efficiency (8.38%).

sections.heading: Dye sensitized solar cell
sections.text:
Intensive efforts have been made in recent years on DSSCs. In this process, sensitizer dyes are absorbed by means of nanoporous semiconductor films as photoanode. In the presence of a photoanode, optical collection efficiency, and charge recombination are affected. The most commonly used photoanodes are TiO2, SnO2, In2O3, Nb2O5, and ZnO,
where ZnO is quite similar to that of TiO2 on account of some similar properties such as a direct bandgap around 3.37 eV and high electron mobility. Better electron diffusivity, however, is provided by ZnO. Hence, ZnO, a photoanode (Figure 4), has more excellent prospect in the field of DSSCs than other metal oxides.
The photovoltaic property of DSSC was investigated by Dhamodharan et al. They grew Al-doped ZnO (AZO) thin film on ITO substrates, and then used these films and natural dye as photoanode and sensitizer, respectively.[39] AZO thin films were obtained by spray pyrolysis method and were deposited onto ITO glass substrates. They also discussed that whether the Al/Zn ratio has an impact on optical and electrical performance, structural or microstructural of these films obtained in this way. Dhamodharan et al. found that pure AZO thin film is used as photoanodes can great enhance the cell property of DSSC. The designed photoanodes was disposed through different natural dye extracts.
Wang et al.[40] also studied the transparent, double-sided, and flexible, ITO-free DSSC with highly ordered, high-crystal-quality, high-density ZnO NW arrays as working electrodes and a Pt wire as the counter electrode. The ZnO NW arrays were radially grown on Au, Ag, Cu, and stainless steel microwires (Fe for short). One of the most promising advantages of the DSSC is that the two metal wires were encased in electrolyte between two PET films or polydimethylsiloxane films to afford the flexibility and high transparency of devices. Based on this study, Wang et al. concluded that the single crystalline with smooth surfaces of nanowires may improve electron diffusion. This is because a direct route for electron transport from the point of electron injection to the metal wire was provide as the electrons would not suffer any grain-boundary scattering.[41] They also systematically investigated that the photovoltaic performance of the DSSCs influenced by dye thickness and deduced an optimized dye-loading time of 20minutes, which results in the best device performance. To prevent the production of galvanic-cell effect, an oxidation treatment of the metal wires was carried out. It is vital for practical application of the DSSC configurations with two metal wires.
Figure 3. (a) SEM image of the Ag NW/ZnO composite transparent electrodes. (b) Ag NWs/PES film-based flexible IOSCs and SEM image of the cross-section.[35]
Other studies proved that ZnO nanomaterials offer unique optical properties, making it possible to use them as photoanodes in the process of DSSC preparation.[42–47]

sections.heading: Perovskite solar cells (PSCs)
sections.text:
PSCs have developed rapidly over the past few years, and now the battery efficiency has soared from 3.8% in 2009 to 22.1%, which is one of the hot spots of the current researches in the solar cell field.[25,48–53] The PSCs are usually composed of electron transport materials, holed transmission materials, perovskite absorption layers, and electrodes. ZnO is considered to be a good electronic transmission material for PSCs. Not only does ZnO material have a similar energy level position and physical properties to TiO2 but also much higher electron mobility. [54,55] Therefore, ZnO would have a significant potential in thin film solar cells, if it be used as an electro transport layer (ETL) material. Different methods were reported for the production of ETLs utilizing ZnO materials. For instance, sputtering grown AZO thin film on ITO substrate showed higher efficiency and stability. Tseng et al.[56] successful prepared AZO thin film by a sputtering method, and on this basis the acquired perovskite cell was achieved the highest power conversion efficiency of 17.6% with Voc of 1.07V. They[57] also discovered that the battery’s carrier extraction efficiency and the battery performance can be effectively improved by controlling the oxygen/argon ratio used in the preparation of ZnO thin films.
The ZnO nanowire (NW) was also studied by Dymshits et al.[58] In their experiment, ZnO NW, as a photoanode, played a key role for perovskite-based solar cells. According to their report, the structure of solar cell was composed of FTO (SnO2: F)-glass on, PET/zinc acetate dehydrates (ZnAc) seed layer/ZnO NWs/CH3NH3PbI3/Spiro-OMeTAD/
Au (Figure 5(a)). They studied the conversion efficiency of the ZnO NWs perovskite-based solar cell on a rigid substrate and found a high efficiency of 9.06% with current density of 21.5mA/cm2. Furthermore, the fabricated ZnO NWs PSCs demonstrates excellent stability over 75 bending cycles with power conversion efficiency of 6.4%, during which the efficiency dropped <20% from its initial value (Figure 5(b)). Their findings make ZnO NWs as an efficient alternative to low temperature photoanode and are thus extraordinarily promising in perovskite-based solar cells.

sections.heading: Flexible solar cells
sections.text: Under moderate vertical pressure, research on the use of piezo-phototronic effect in solar energy conversion efficiency was carried out by Zhu et al.[59] On the basis of the n-ZnO/ p-SnS core–shell NW array, they carried out this experiment. The designed ZnO/SnS heterojunction can effectively to enhance the character of separation and transport of photogenerated carriers. Performance can improve because driving force of the band structure of the designed heterojunction adopted piezoelectric potential of ZnO NW array. The gentle bending of the designed heterojunction is a key factor in effectively to enhance the property of all kinds of solar cell, which has a great promising in the world of curly geometries. These results indicated that the piezophototronic effect not only increases solar energy conversion efficiency, but also has a great potential for application in solar cells.

sections.heading: Supercapacitors
sections.text:
SC, as a new energy-storage device, not only has the characteristics of capacitor quick charge and discharge, but also battery energy storage. The materials of electrode, as a key
Figure 4. (a) Illustration of the molecular mechanisms underlying the functioning of a ZnO-based dye-sensitized solar cell.[37] (b) A schematic view of the flexible DSSC.[38] (c) Flexible DSSC.
determinant of the performance of SCs, have triggered great research interest, especially ZnO nanomaterials.[60,61] Hydrogenated ZnO NWs have higher electrochemical activity and conductivity than unhydrogenated ZnO NWs. Based on this finding, a new kind of flexible all-solid-state SC configuration was fabricated by Yang et al.[62] (Figure 6(a)), which consists of two pieces of slightly separated carbon cloth grown with shell nanocable (HZM) as electrodes and PVA/LiCl gel as solid-state electrolyte. It shows that areal and specific capacitance has a value of 138.7 mF/cm2 and 1260.9 F/g, respectively. Besides, huge performance benefit of SC applications was showed. For example, its capacitance and flexibility are higher, life span is longer, and leakage current is lower. In an independent self-powered system, the HZM flexible SCs, as a switchable power (Figure 6(b)), have a wide application prospect in the field of the optoelectronic devices. Ren et al.[63] used ZnO NWs/Ni hybrid core-shell structure as pseudo-capacitor electrode for SCs and investigated its capacitance properties. The three values reflecting the capacitance performance from electrochemical measurement are specific capacitance (2440 Fg 1), rate capability (80.5%), and cycling stability (86.74%). The results showed that the samples have excellent capacitive properties and are a prospective electrodes material for SCs.

sections.heading: Flexible piezoelectric NGs
sections.text:
ZnO nanomaterials are a kind of ideal material used to surface and volume acoustic wave, which have eminent piezoelectricity properties like low permittivity, high electromechanical coupling coefficient, and so on. Therefore, ZnO nanomaterials can be applied more broadly to piezoelectric device as piezoelectric materials.[64,65]
Lately, a neoteric method was used by Liao et al.[66] to synthesize flexible piezoelectric NGs consisting of foldable Au-coated ZnO NWs on paper and ZnO NWs on carbon fibers, which can be used in converting mechanical energy into electricity. They used a two-step hydrothermal method to prepare ZnO NWs on paper and carbon fibers. Compared to the single-fiber based NG techniques, the multi-fiber-based NG made of 200 carbon fibers achieved an alternating current output, which increases 35 nA. By employing four-point probes to measure the surface resistances of Au-coated ZnO/paper and showed that the Aucoated ZnO-papers are regard as foldable contact electrodes because of their excellent conductivity, which greatly increased the effective working ZnO NWs and the corresponding current density reached to 0.09 lA cm 2. They reported the NGs can produce so huge electrical energy that can provided for use by many practical devices; for instance, wearable devices.
Recently, Shin et al.[67] developed high performance flexible piezoelectric NGs using Li-doped ZnO NWs (Figure 7(a)). Li-doped ZnO NWs grown by mixing hydrothermally exhibited that a relatively high piezoelectric coefficient compared to intrinsic ZnO NWs. In addition, the manufacturing technique of NG so simple that fabricating large-scale equipment may be used this method. When the periodic bending/ releasing of NGs was measured, they found that the voltage and current were not only stable but also renewable. Through testing, voltage and current were reached for 180V and 50 lA, respectively (Figure 7(b)).
Zhang et al.[68] used sputtering with a Cu (99.99%) target to prepare piezoelectric NGs. To enhance the output performance of the flexible piezoelectric nanogenerator based on ZnO, they used halogen elements (fluorine, chlorine,
Figure 5. (a) SEM cross section of the flexible ZnO NWs CH 3 NH 3 PbI 3 PSC. (b) Stability of the flexible solar cell under bending.[58]
Figure 6. (a) Schematic diagram of a solid-state HZM SC. (b) Schematic of a stand-alone self-powered system consisting of four series-wound DSSCs, three serieswound flexible SCs, and one LED.[62]
bromine, and iodine) as dopant to prepare ZnO NW films (Figure 8(b)). They built the lattice strain associated with doping concentration along ZnO c-axis and confirmed by energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS), XRD, and HRTEM studies (Figure 8(a)). It was found that piezoelectric semiconductor nanomaterials have a great prospective in the field of constructing more excellent efficiency piezoelectric nanodevices. Because the lattice distortion improves the performance of wurtzite type piezoelectric semiconductor nanomaterials.
UV PD
In recent years, UV PD has received extensive attention, because its wavelength is alternative, responsivity is low, and sensitivity is higher than other PDs and so on. UV PDs have important applications in the field of military and medical, such as missile tracking, flame sensing, encrypted signal transmission, UV calibration and monitoring, and so forth. Nanostructure semiconductor materials are considered to have potential for UV PDs due to wide band up energy. In particular, ZnO nanomaterials exhibit their great potential in high response UV PD due to their direct wide band gap energy (3.37 eV) with high exciton binding energy (60meV).
Having good photoresponses, high stability, and facile fabrication methods are essential conditions for fabricating novel PDs. These can be achieved by an optimized electrospinning method on the basis of NW arrays due to a broadspectrum response range, high stability, and fast response speed.[69] Zheng et al. fabricated ZnO-CdO hybrid NWs arrays via the following steps. The ZnO and CdO parts were fused into the same NWs, and then assembled into a standard structure. On the basis of a study of the optoelectronic and electronic properties of the ZnO-CdO hybrid NW arrays, authors fabricated an array of transparent and flexible ZnO-CdO PDs with 95% transparency in 400–800 nm spectral region. What’s more, they through 200 bending cycles and can keep their properties. It is noted that the simple method paves the route for efficient PD fabrication.
Tran et al.[18] reported a facile technique to synthesize a microsized flexible ZnO UV PDs, which is called inkjet printing. After multiple deforming periods, the mechanical bending makes no difference to working performance. The phenomenon reflected the devices, which synthesized by the additive manufacturing method, have excellent bendability. The shortest response time as low as 0.3 seconds, and highest on/off ratio of 3525, respectively. By these results, they concluded that the device has a significant potential in the field of wearable in-situ monitoring UV sensors. Wang et al.[70] used ferroelectric localized field to prepare a ZnO

nanosheet UV PD with preeminent property, namely, a high responsivity (3.8 105 AW 1) and a detective (4.4 1015 Jones).

sections.heading: Photodiodes
sections.text:
In recent years, Si-based flexible light-emitting diode (LED) array devices have been widely studied. Unfortunately, Si wire array devices that utilizing the specific optical and electrical properties also faced some challenges, especially for the Si wire-based flexible LED array devices. Li et al.[71] produced flexible n-ZnO/p-Si heterostructure LEDs, with the advantages of flexibility, long lifetime, stability, lightweight, and energy savings at room temperature. ZnO thin films (60W 45min) and Ag layers were obtained by magnetron sputtering, these forming the n-type layer and the electrodes. They used a sharp blade to peel off the flexible polymer/Si microwire array/ZnO composite film from the Si wafer mechanically and then deposited an electrode on its reverse side. In this study, ZnO of the flexible LED prominently enhances the emission efficiency and notably decreases the heat emitted from the photons in the Si material. They also studied the light emission performances of the flexible LED array device (Figure 9). The flexible LED array device, which prepared by transferring Si microcolumns-Zn nanofilm, has two characters. The first peculiarity is continuous illumination more than 24 hours. And the second peculiarity is opening and closing in excess of 1011 times when the impulse voltage frequency is 1MHz.
Lim et al.[72] developed a flexible PD with excellent highly efficient omnidirectional light-absorption ability and broadband light-detection capability by with an ultra-flexible and hierarchical ZnO NW/Si honeycomb photodiode membrane (Figure 10) with not only a fast response time but a broad photoresponse range spanning the UV to near infrared reflection. And, more remarkable, in flexible PDs they achieved broad-band omnidirectional light detection. A
hierarchical photodiode of ZnO NWs on honeycombstructured Si (H-Si) membranes can detect omnidirectional light. The ZnO NW/H-Si flexible photodiodes not only provide better mechanical flexibility because of the advantageous honeycomb structure but also revealed extremely high mechanical durability.[73]
The first indium-gallium-zinc-oxide (IGZO) Schottky diodes were fabricated on flexible plastic substrates by Zhang et al.,[74] which cutoff frequency is 6.3GHz. The developed IGZO-based Schottky diodes have a higher the critical benchmark speed electronic components. Furthermore, the main frequency bands of smart phones here are Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, global satellite positioning, cellular communication and all of these are satisfied. Notably, they studied the thicknesses and diode sizes of many IGZO and concluded that the diode speed has an unexpected effect for the IGZO thickness, namely, with the increase of the thickness of IGZO layer, the high frequency performance becomes better. Benlamri et al.[75] also fabricated Cu/ZnO Schottky diodes on flexible PI substrates that have potential capabilities to retain device operationality with good performance under mechanical deformations. The high-quality ZnO films optimized for electronic performance was synthesized on a flexible substrate by a low-cost electrodeposition technique. A Schottky diode with high rectification ratios ( 106) and low ideality factors ( 2–3) was constituted by Cu/ZnO system.

sections.heading: Flexible and porous 3-D ceramics
sections.text:
Flexible and porous 3-D ceramics made from inorganic metal oxide nanostructures and microstructures have received great attention, which likely to become material candidates for future nanotechnologies
By the green route, which synthesized through a versatile flame transport, Gr€ottrup et al.[76] synthesized 3-D interconnected networks on the basis of pure and metal-alloyed ZnO
Figure 9. (a) Schematic structure of the flexible LED array device. (b) Pressure distribution mapping under different pressure by the LEDs array intensity image. (c) Comparison between three different similar structures of ZnO/Si LED array devices: (d) SC LED, (e) DCSS, and (f) flexible LED.[71]
nanoscale and microscale tetrapod (ZnO-T). Based on this study, Gr€ottrup et al. concluded that ZnO-T networks display a higher Young’s modulus and elastic limit than pure ZnO networks. The experiments showed that 3-D networks may play a very important role compared to the binary counterparts. The 3-D networks have an essential influence to sensors, photocatalytic activities, photoanode, and photonic energy conversion.

sections.heading: Functional surface coating
sections.text:
Functional surface coating belongs to a kind of nanocoating, which can be applied to traditional material matrix, powder particles and fibers for surface modification, coating, and other new properties (such as enhancing the interaction in a composite structure,[77] resisting friction and bacterium on the surface of metal materials,[78] and improving the flameretardant property of cotton fabric[79]).
Tian et al.[80] prepared the functional flexible cellulosic surfaces coating on flexible cellulose materials (filter papers) by a coating method with ZnO nanoparticles and binds of renewable soybean oil-based polymers (Figure 11). The functional flexible surfaces are significant for medical or packaging applications due to their high water-resistance and antimicrobial performances. In this process, self-aggregation of ZnO nanoparticles formed ZnO particles with two regular morphological patterns (a rod-like morphology and a flower-like ZnO), and the flower-like ZnO effectively promoted the static contact angles, antimicrobial activities surface and surface hydrophobicity. Moreover, rather than a rod-like structural pattern of ZnO, a flower-like ZnO showed a 51.6% promotion on antimicrobial activities inhibit Gram-negative bacteria (Escherichia coli). A binder/ ZnO ratio of 0.2 led to a remarkable improvement on water repelling performances yet without negative effects on a coating adhesion of ZnO.

sections.heading: Gas sensors
sections.text:
ZnO nanomaterials are one of the important semiconductor materials, which widely used as an effective gas sensor
element because their high accuracy and reproducibility for the chemical sensitivity detection of volatile and other toxic gases. It is mainly to monitor environmental pollution for home and industrial safety.[81] The sensitivity of such devices depends on temperature, sensitivity increases as the temperature up to a certain value increase.[82–84] However, the further temperature growth leads to decrease in the sensor sensitivity. As a consequence, there is an optimum temperature value corresponding to the maximum sensitivity of the sample, namely, from 200 to 400 C.
Kim et al.[85] successfully synthesized micropatternable double-faced (DF) ZnO nanoflowers (NFs) gas sensor on PI substrate, which has the maximizing surface area. In this process of preparing, single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) were used as a PI substrate for the electrode. The DF-ZnO NF gas sensor exhibited high selectivity toward NO2 and upon NO2 exposure showed perfect saturation behavior and outstanding sensing performances, and they schematically described the fabrication steps of it. The experiments result showed that the devices have outstanding sensing characteristics and the responsible reasons for its better sensor performance are a combination of high surface area and numerous active points from the NRs, the ZnO point defects of the donor state, and the SWCNT electrode.

sections.heading: Biosensors
sections.text:
Biosensor, an analytical device, was consists of a biometric and transducer. Furthermore, there has been an increasing interest in nanosized biosensors based on ZnO nanomaterials, since they have been used in the combination of various biosensing molecules.[86–88]
For the biosensor technology, with the development of nanotechnology, not only the miniaturization has improved but also multifunctionality has ameliorated. The sketch of a biosensor (Figure 12) made clear that to receive dependable and comprehensive support sensing biomolecules need to be integrated into the system.
Via flexographic printed technique, Assaifan et al.[90] produced ZnO thin films, which formed a nanotextured surface in the process of prepare. It is great for biosensing devices with highly sensitive to afford a fantastic platform. Such surface nanostructures with excellent performance for
Figure 10. The fabrication process for the ZnO NWs/H–Si PDs on SiO2/Si substrates.[72]
maximizing surface functionalization are essential to high sensitivity detect for diseases. It is important to note that nonfaradaic biosensors, which fabricated through the printing technique, were used for detection the pp65-antigen of human cytomegalovirus, and the test result was 5 pg/mL.
Cao et al.[91] presented a label-free DNA sensor with sensitive and in situ selective, which used a Schottkycontacted ZnO NW device as a basis. The performances of the ZnO NW DNA sensor were also studied by Cao et al. using its output currents. In the process of researching properties, they measured it by under different external strains and target complementary deoxyribonucleic acid (cDNA) concentrations. The results indicated that utilizing the piezotronic effect can largely improve the output currents and the difference between two target cDNA concentrations. It is no longer a problem for DNA to carry out the label-free detection, because the authors provided a piezotronic-assisted method.

sections.heading: Discussions
sections.text:
With the development of new preparation methods and more preferable characterization techniques, better performance and new applications of ZnO nanomaterials are also found and created, which enabled ZnO nanomaterials to have the widespread interest in recent years.
This ZnO nanomaterial, by reason of its many interesting properties, showed great promise for flexible functional
devices. In this article, recent developments on preparation and applications of ZnO in flexible function nanomaterials have been discussed.
As can be seen from the survey of recent literature presented here, ZnO nanomaterials can be produced by many different methods. All the existing methods have their own advantages, and the characteristics of ZnO nanomaterials that produced by those methods are also different. For nanoscale structures and devices, ZnO nanomaterials are more advantageous as compared with other nanostructured metal oxides, and the functional devices of this materials structure have been produced and marketed. As one of the promising semiconductor materials, ZnO has been successfully used in each area, including battery, energy storage, semiconductor devices, ceramics, nanocoating, and sensors. Despite some success, the new fabrication methods, key factors controlling the stability of the materials, and functionality applications still need to further study to enable ZnO materials to have a better performance in broader spectrum of applications.

metadata.abstractText: The present review focuses on the preparations, properties, and applications of zinc oxide (ZnO) nanomaterials in flexible functional devices. An overview is given on several methods for the growth of ZnO nanomaterials, including sputtering, sol-gel method, atomic layer deposition, allinkjet-printing approach, electrochemical deposition, hydrothermal method. The broad applications of ZnO nanomaterials in solar cell, supercapacitors, flexible piezoelectric nanogenerators, ultraviolet photodetectors, photodiodes, porous three-dimensional (3-D) ceramics, functional surface coating, and sensors are also discussed.
